div.head: Act 1, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter a company of mutinous Citizens, with staves, clubs, and other weapons.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Before we proceed any further, hear me speak.

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Speak, speak.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You are all resolved rather to die than to famish?

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Resolved, resolved.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the
people.

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: We know't, we know't.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Let us kill him, and we'll have corn at our own price.
Is't a verdict?

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: No more talking on't; let it be done: away, away!

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: One word, good citizens.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians
good. What authority surfeits on would relieve
us: if they would yield us but the superfluity,
while it were wholesome, we might guess they
relieved us humanely; but they think we are too
dear: the leanness that afflicts us, the object
of our misery, is as an inventory to particularize
their abundance; our sufferance is a gain to
them. Let us revenge this with our pikes, ere we
become rakes: for the gods know I speak this in hunger
for bread, not in thirst for revenge.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Would you proceed especially against Caius Marcius?

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Against him first: he's a very dog to the commonalty.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Consider you what services he has done for his
country?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Very well; and could be content to give him good
report for't, but that he pays himself with being
proud.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Nay, but speak not maliciously.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: I say unto you, what he hath done famously, he
did it to that end: though soft-conscienced men
can be content to say it was for his country, he
did it to please his mother, and to be partly
proud; which he is, even to the altitude of his
virtue.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: What he cannot help in his nature, you account
a vice in him. You must in no way say he is covetous.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: If I must not, I need not be barren of accusations;
he hath faults, with surplus, to tire in repetition.
What shouts are these? The other side a' the city is
risen: why stay we prating here? to the Capitol!

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Come, come.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Soft! who comes here?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Worthy Menenius Agrippa; one that hath always loved
the people.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: He's one honest enough: would all the rest were so!

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: What work's, my countrymen, in hand? where go you
With bats and clubs? The matter? speak, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Our business is not unknown to the senate; they
have had inkling this fortnight what we intend
to do, which now we'll show 'em in deeds. They
say poor suitors have strong breaths: they shall know
we have strong arms too.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Why, masters, my good friends, mine honest neighbours,
Will you undo yourselves?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We cannot, sir, we are undone already.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: I tell you, friends, most charitable care
Have the patricians of you. For your wants,
Your suffering in this dearth, you may as well
Strike at the heaven with your staves as lift them
Against the Roman state, whose course will on
The way it takes, cracking ten thousand curbs
Of more strong link asunder than can ever
Appear in your impediment. For the dearth,
The gods, not the patricians, make it, and
Your knees to them, not arms, must help. Alack,
You are transported by calamity
Thither where more attends you, and you slander
The helms o' the state, who care for you like fathers,
When you curse them as enemies.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Care for us! True, indeed! They ne'er cared for
us yet: suffer us to famish, and their storehouses
crammed with grain; make edicts for usury, to
support usurers; repeal daily any wholesome act
established against the rich, and provide more
piercing statutes daily, to chain up and restrain
the poor. If the wars eat us not up, they will; and
there's all the love they bear us.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Either you must
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
Or be accused of folly. I shall tell you
A pretty tale: it may be you have heard it;
But, since it serves my purpose, I will venture
To stale't a little more.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Well, I'll hear it, sir: yet you must not think
to fob off our disgrace with a tale: but, and't please
you, deliver.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: There was a time when all the body's members
Rebelled against the belly, thus accused it:
That only like a gulf it did remain
I' the midst o' the body, idle and unactive,
Still cupboarding the viand, never bearing
Like labour with the rest, where the other instruments
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
And, mutually participate, did minister
Unto the appetite and affection common
Of the whole body. The belly answered

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Well, sir, what answer made the belly?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Sir, I shall tell you. With a kind of smile,
Which ne'er came from the lungs, but even thus,
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
As well as speak â it tauntingly replied
To the discontented members, the mutinous parts
That envied his receipt; even so most fitly
As you malign our senators for that
They are not such as you.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Your belly's answer? What?
The kingly-crowned head, the vigilant eye,
The counsellor heart, the arm our soldier,
Our steed the leg, the tongue our trumpeter,
With other muniments and petty helps
In this our fabric, if that they

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: What then?
'Fore me, this fellow speaks! What then? what then?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Should by the cormorant belly be restrained,
Who is the sink a' the body,

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: The former agents, if they did complain,
What could the belly answer?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: I will tell you;
If you'll bestow a small ( of what you have little)
Patience awhile, you'st hear the belly's answer.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Y' are long about it.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Note me this, good friend;
Your most grave belly was deliberate,
Not rash like his accusers, and thus answered:
âTrue is it, my incorporate friends,â quoth he,
âThat I receive the general food at first,
Which you do live upon; and fit it is,
Because I am the storehouse and the shop
Of the whole body: but, if you do remember,
I send it through the rivers of your blood,
Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;
And, through the cranks and offices of man,
The strongest nerves and small inferior veins
From me receive that natural competency
Whereby they live: and though that all at once,
You, my good friends,â this says the belly, mark me,

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Ay, sir; well, well.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: âThough all at once cannot
See what I do deliver out to each,
Yet I can make my audit up, that all
From me do back receive the flour of all,
And leave me but the bran.â What say you to't?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: It was an answer: how apply you this?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: The senators of Rome are this good belly,
And you the mutinous members; for examine
Their counsels and their cares: digest things rightly
Touching the weal a' the common, you shall find
No public benefit which you receive
But it proceeds or comes from them to you
And no way from yourselves. What do you think,
You, the great toe of this assembly?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: I the great toe! why the great toe?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest,
Of this most wise rebellion, thou go'st foremost:
Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
Lead'st first to win some vantage.
But make you ready your stiff bats and clubs:
Rome and her rats are at the point of battle;
The one side must have bale. Enter CAIUS MARCIUS.
Hail, noble Marcius.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Thanks. What's the matter, you dissentious rogues,
That, rubbing the poor itch of your opinion,
Make yourselves scabs?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: We have ever your good word.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: He that will give good words to thee will flatter
Beneath abhorring. What would you have, you curs,
That like nor peace nor war? the one affrights you,
The other makes you proud. He that trusts to you,
Where he should find you lions, finds you hares;
Where foxes, geese: you are no surer, no,
Than is the coal of fire upon the ice,
Or hailstone in the sun. Your virtue is
To make him worthy whose offence subdues him
And curse that justice did it. Who deserves greatness
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
A sick man's appetite, who desires most that
Which would increase his evil. He that depends
Upon your favours swims with fins of lead
And hews down oaks with rushes. Hang ye! Trust ye?
With every minute you do change a mind,
And call him noble that was now your hate,
Him vile that was your garland. What's the matter,
That in these several places of the city
You cry against the noble senate, who,
Under the gods, keep you in awe, which else
Would feed on one another? What's their seeking?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: For corn at their own rates; whereof they say,
The city is well stored.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Hang'em! They say!
They'll sit by the fire, and presume to know
What's done i' the Capitol; who's like to rise,
Who thrives and who declines; side factions and give out
Conjectural marriages; making parties strong
And feebling such as stand not in their liking
Below their cobbled shoes. They say there's grain enough!
Would the nobility lay aside their ruth,
And let me use my sword, I'ld make a quarry
With thousands of these quartered slaves, as high
As I could pick my lance.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Nay, these are almost thoroughly persuaded;
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
Yet are they passing cowardly. But, I beseech you,
What says the other troop?

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: They are dissolved: hang'em!
They said they were an-hungry; sighed forth proverbs,
That hunger broke stone walls, that dogs must eat,
That meat was made for mouths, that the gods sent not
Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds
They vented their complainings; which being answered,
And a petition granted them, a strange one
To break the heart of generosity,
And make bold power look pale â they threw their caps
As they would hang them on the horns a' the moon,
Shouting their emulation.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: What is granted them?

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
Of their own choice: one's Junius Brutus,
Sicinius Velutus, and I know not â 'Sdeath!
The rabble should have first unroofed the city,
Ere so prevailed with me: it will in time
Win upon power and throw forth greater themes
For insurrection's arguing.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: This is strange.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Go, get you home, you fragments! Enter a Messenger, hastily.

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Where's Caius Marcius?

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Here: what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The news is, sir, the Volsces are in arms.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I am glad on't: then we shall ha' means to vent
Our musty superfluity. See, our best elders. Enter COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators; JUNIUS BRUTUS and SICINIUS VELUTUS.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Marcius, 'tis true that you have lately told us;
The Volsces are in arms.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: They have a leader,
Tullus Aufidius, that will put you to't.
I sin in envying his nobility,
And were I any thing but what I am,
I would wish me only he.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: You have fought together.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Were half to half the world by the ears and he
Upon my party, I'ld revolt, to make
Only my wars with him: he is a lion
That I am proud to hunt.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Then, worthy Marcius,
Attend upon Cominius to these wars.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: It is your former promise.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Sir, it is;
And I am constant. Titus Lartius, thou
Shalt see me once more strike at Tullus' face.
What, art thou stiff? stand'st out?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: No, Caius Marcius;
I'll lean upon one crutch and fight with t' other,
Ere stay behind this business.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: O, true-bred!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Your company to the Capitol; where, I know,
Our greatest friends attend us.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Lead you on. To Mar.
Follow Cominius; we must follow you;
Right worthy you priority.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Noble Marcius!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Hence to your homes; be gone!

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Nay, let them follow:
The Volsces have much corn; take these rats thither
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners,
Your valour puts well forth: pray, follow. Citizens steal away. Exeunt all but Sicinius and Brutus.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: He has no equal.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: When we were chosen tribunes for the people,

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Marked you his lip and eyes?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Nay, but his taunts.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Being moved, he will not spare to gird the gods

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Bemock the modest moon.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: The present wars devour him: he is grown
Too proud to be so valiant.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Such a nature,
Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Which he treads on at noon: but I do wonder
His insolence can brook to be commanded
Under Cominius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Fame, at the which he aims,
In whom already he's well graced, cannot
Better be held nor more attained than by
A place below the first: for what miscarries
Shall be the general's fault, though he perform
To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure
Will then cry out of Marcius âO, if he
Had borne the business!â

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Besides, if things go well,
Opinion that so sticks on Marcius shall
Of his demerits rob Cominius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Come:
Half all Cominius' honours are to Marcius,
Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults
To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed
In aught he merit not.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Let's hence, and hear
How the dispatch is made, and in what fashion,
More than his singularity, he goes
Upon this present action.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Let's along. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS and certain Senators.

sp.speaker: First Senators
sp.l: So, your opinion is, Aufidius,
That they of Rome are entered in our counsels
And know how we proceed.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: Is it not yours?
What ever have been thought on in this state,
That could be brought to bodily act ere Rome
Had circumvention? 'Tis not four days gone
Since I heard thence; these are the words: I think
I have the letter here; yes, here it is. Reads
âThey have pressed a power, but it is not known
Whether for east or west: the dearth is great;
The people mutinous; and it is rumoured,
Cominius Marcius your old enemy,
Who is of Rome worse hated than of you,
And Titus Lartius, a most valiant Roman,
These three lead on this preparation
Whither 'tis bent: most likely 'tis for you:
Consider of it.â

sp.speaker: First Senators
sp.l: Our army's in the field:
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
To answer us.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: Nor did you think it folly
To keep your great pretences veiled till when
They needs must show themselves; which in the hatching,
It seemed, appeared to Rome. By the discovery
We shall be shortened in our aim, which was
To take in many towns ere almost Rome
Should know we were afoot.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: Noble Aufidius,
Take your commission; hie you to your bands:
Let us alone to guard Corioles:
If they set down before's, for the remove
Bring up your army; but, I think, you'll find
Th' have not prepared for us.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: O, doubt not that;
I speak from certainties. Nay, more,
Some parcels of their power are forth already,
And only hitherward. I leave your honours.
If we and Caius Marcius chance to meet,
'Tis sworn between us we shall ever strike
Till one can do no more.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: The gods assist you!

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: And keep your honours safe!

sp.speaker: First Senators
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Second Senator
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Farewell. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 3
div.stage: Rome. A room in Marcius' house.
Enter VOLUMNIA and VIRGILIA: they set them down on two low stools, and sew.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: I pray you, daughter, sing; or express yourself
in a more comfortable sort: if my son were my
husband, I should freelier rejoice in that absence
wherein he won honour than in the embracements
of his bed where he would show most love. When
yet he was but tender-bodied and the only son of
my womb, when youth with comeliness plucked all
gaze his way, when for a day of kings' entreaties
a mother should not sell him an hour from her
beholding, I, considering how honour would become
such a person, that it was no better than
picture-like to hang by the wall, if renown made
it not stir, was pleased to let him seek danger
where he was like to find fame. To a cruel war
I sent him; from whence he returned, his brows
bound with oak. I tell thee, daughter, I sprang
not more in joy at first hearing he was a man-child
than now in first seeing he had proved himself a man.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: But had he died in the business, madam; how then?

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Then his good report should have been my son; I
therein would have found issue. Hear me profess
sincerely: had I a dozen sons, each in my love
alike and none less dear than thine and my good
Marcius, I had rather had eleven die nobly for
their country than one voluptuously surfeit out of
action.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman
sp.l: Madam, the Lady Valeria is come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.l: Beseech you, give me leave to retire myself.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.l: Indeed, you shall not.
Methinks I hear hither your husband's drum,
See him pluck Aufidius down by the hair,
As children from a bear, the Volsces shunning him:
Methinks I see him stamp thus, and call thus:
âCome on, you cowards! you were got in fear,
Though you were born in Rome:â his bloody brow
With his mailed hand then wiping, forth he goes,
Like to a harvest-man that's tasked to mow
Or all or lose his hire.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.l: His bloody brow! O Jupiter, no blood!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.l: Away, you fool! it more becomes a man
Than gilt his trophy: the breasts of Hecuba,
When she did suckle Hector, looked not lovelier
Than Hector's forehead when it spit forth blood
At Grecian sword, contemning. Tell Valeria,
We are fit to bid her welcome. Exit Gent.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.l: Heavens bless my lord from fell Aufidius!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.l: He'll beat Aufidius' head below his knee
And tread upon his neck. Enter VALERIA, with an Usher and Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: My ladies both, good day to you.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Sweet madam.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: I am glad to see your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: How do you both? you are manifest housekeepers.
What are you sewing here? A fine spot, in good faith.
How does your little son?

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: I thank your ladyship; well, good madam.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: He had rather see the swords, and hear a drum, than
look upon his schoolmaster.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: A' my word, the father's son: I'll swear, 'tis
a very pretty boy. A' my troth, I looked upon
him a' Wednesday half an hour together: he's such
a confirmed countenance. I saw him run after a
gilded butterfly; and when he caught it, he let
it go again; and after it again; and over and
over he comes, and up again; catched it again;
or whether his fall enraged him, or how 'twas,
he did so set his teeth and tear it; O, I warrant, how
he mammocked it!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: One on's father's moods.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Indeed, la, 'tis a noble child.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: A crack, madam.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Come, lay aside your stitchery; I must have you play
the idle huswife with me this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: No, good madam; I will not out of doors.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Not out of doors!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: She shall, she shall.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: Indeed, no, by your patience: I'll not over the
threshold till my lord return from the wars.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably:
come, you must go visit the good lady that lies in.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: I will wish her speedy strength, and visit her with my
prayers; but I cannot go thither.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Why, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: 'Tis not to save labour, nor that I want love.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: You would be another Penelope: yet, they say,
all the yarn she spun in Ulysses' absence did
but fill Ithaca full of moths. Come; I would your
cambric were sensible as your finger, that you
might leave pricking it for pity. Come, you shall go
with us.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: No, good madam, pardon me; indeed, I will not forth.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: In truth, la, go with me; and I'll tell you excellent
news of your husband.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: O, good madam, there can be none yet.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Verily, I do not jest with you; there came news from
him last night.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: Indeed, madam?

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: In earnest, it's true; I heard a senator speak
it. Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth;
against whom Cominius the general is gone, with
one part of our Roman power: your lord and Titus
Lartius are set down before their city Corioles;
they nothing doubt prevailing and to make it
brief wars. This is true, on mine honour; and so, I
pray, go with us.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every
thing hereafter.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Let her alone, lady: as she is now, she will but
disease our better mirth.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: In troth, I think she would. Fare you well, then.
Come, good sweet lady. Prithee, Virgilia, turn thy
solemness out a' door, and go along with us.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: No, at a word, madam; indeed, I must not. I wish you
much mirth.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: Well, then, farewell.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 4
div.stage: Enter, with drum and colours, MARCIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, Captains and Soldiers. To them a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Yonder comes news. A wager they have met.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: My horse to yours, no.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: 'Tis done.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Say, has our general met the enemy?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: They lie in view; but have not spoke as yet.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: So, the good horse is mine.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I'll buy him of you.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: No, I'll nor sell nor give him: lend you him I will
For half a hundred years. Summon the town.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: How far off lie these armies?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Within this mile and half.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Then shall we hear their 'larum, and they ours.
Now, Mars, I prithee, make us quick in work,
That we with smoking swords may march from hence,
To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast. They sound a parley. Enter two Senators with others on the walls.
Tullus Aufidius, is he within your walls?

sp.speaker: First Senators
sp.l: No, nor a man that fears you less than he,
That's lesser than a little. Drums afar off.
Hark! our drums
Are bringing forth our youth. We'll break our walls,
Rather than they shall pound us up: our gates,
Which yet seem shut, we have but pinned with rushes;
They'll open of themselves. Alarum afar off.
Hark you, far off!
There is Aufidius; list, what work he makes
Amongst your cloven army.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: O, they are at it!

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Their noise be our instruction. Ladders, ho! Enter the army of the Volsces.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: They fear us not, but issue forth their city.
Now put your shields before your hearts, and fight
With hearts more proof than shields. Advance, brave Titus:
They do disdain us much beyond our thoughts,
Which makes me sweat with wrath. Come on, my fellows:
He that retires, I'll take him for a Volsce,
And he shall feel mine edge. Alarum. The Romans are beat back to their trenches. Re-enter MARCIUS, cursing.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: All the contagion of the south light on you,
You shames of Rome? you herd of â Boils and plagues
Plaster you o'er, that you may be abhorred
Further than seen and one infect another
Against the wind a mile! You souls of geese,
That bear the shapes of men, how have you run
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
All hurt behind; backs red, and faces pale
With fright and agued fear! Mend and charge home,
Or, by the fires of heaven, I'll leave the foe
And make my wars on you: look to't: come on:
If you'll stand fast, we'll beat them to their wives,
As they us to our trenches follow's. Another alarum. The Volsces fly, and MARCIUS follows them to the gates.
So, now the gates are ope: now prove good seconds:
'Tis for the followers fortune widens them,
Not for the fliers: mark me, and do the like. Enters the gates.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Foolhardiness; not I.

sp.speaker: Second Soldier
sp.l: Nor I. Marcius is shut in.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: See, they have shut him in.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: To the pot, I warrant him. Alarum continues. Re-enter TITUS LARTIUS.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: What is become of Marcius?

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Slain, sir, doubtless.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Following the fliers at the very heels,
With them he enters; who, upon the sudden,
Clapped to their gates: he is himself alone,
To answer all the city.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: O noble fellow!
Who sensibly outdares his senseless sword,
And, when it bows, stand'st up. Thou art left, Marcius:
A carbuncle entire, as big as thou art,
Were not so rich a jewel. Thou wast a soldier
Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible
Only in strokes; but, with thy grim looks and
The thunder-like percussion of thy sounds,
Thou madest thine enemies shake, as if the world
Were feverous and did tremble. Re-enter MARCIUS, bleeding, assaulted by the enemy.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Look, sir.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: O, 'tis Marcius!
Let's fetch him off, or make remain alike. They fight, and all enter the city.

sp.speaker: First Roman
sp.ab: This will I carry to Rome.

sp.speaker: Second Roman
sp.ab: And I this.

sp.speaker: Third Roman
sp.ab: A murrain on't! I took this for silver.
sp.stage: Enter MARCIUS and TITUS LARTIUS with a trumpet.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: See here these movers that do prize their hours
At a cracked drachma! Cushions, leaden spoons,
Irons of a doit, doublets that hangmen would
Bury with those that wore them, these base slaves,
Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!
And hark, what noise the general makes! To him!
There is the man of my soul's hate, Aufidius,
Piercing our Romans: then, valiant Titus, take
Convenient numbers to make good the city;
Whilst I, with those that have the spirit, will haste
To help Cominius.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Worthy sir, thou bleed'st;
Thy exercise hath been too violent for
A second course of fight.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Sir, praise me not;
My work hath yet not warmed me: fare you well:
The blood I drop is rather physical
Than dangerous to me: to Aufidius thus
I will appear, and fight.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Now the fair goddess, Fortune,
Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms
Misguide thy opposers' swords! Bold gentleman,
Prosperity be thy page!

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Thy friend no less
Than those she placeth highest! So, farewell.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Thou worthiest Marcius! Exit Marcius,
Go sound thy trumpet in the marketplace;
Call thither all the officers a' the town,
Where they shall know our mind: away! Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 6
div.stage: Enter COMINIUS, as it were in retire, with soldiers.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Breathe you, my friends: well fought; we are come off
Like Romans, neither foolish in our stands,
Nor cowardly in retire: believe me, sirs,
We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,
By interims and conveying gusts we have heard
The charges of our friends. The Roman gods,
Lead their successes as we wish our own,
That both our powers, with smiling fronts encountering,
May give you thankful sacrifice. Enter a Messenger.
Thy news?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The citizens of Corioles have issued,
And given to Lartius and to Marcius battle:
I saw our party to their trenches driven,
And then I came away.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Though thou speak'st truth,
Methinks thou speak'st not well. How long is't since?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Above an hour, my lord.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: 'Tis not a mile; briefly we heard their drums:
How couldst thou in a mile confound an hour,
And bring thy news so late?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: Spies of the Volsces
Held me in chase, that I was forced to wheel
Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,
Half an hour since brought my report.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Who's yonder,
That does appear as he were flayed? O gods!
He has the stamp of Marcius; and I have
Before-time seen him thus.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Come I too late?

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: The shepherd knows not thunder from a tabor
More than I know the sound of Marcius' tongue
From every meaner man. Enter MARCIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Come I too late?

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Ay, if you come not in the blood of others,
But mantled in your own.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: O, let me clip ye
In arms as sound as when I wooed, in heart
As merry as when our nuptial day was done,
And tapers burned to bedward!

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Flower of warriors,
How is't with Titus Lartius?

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: As with a man busied about decrees:
Condemning some to death, and some to exile;
Ransoming him, or pitying, threatening the other;
Holding Corioles in the name of Rome,
Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
To let him slip at will.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Where is that slave
Which told me they had beat you to your trenches?
Where is he? call him hither.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Let him alone;
He did inform the truth: but for our gentlemen,
The common file â a plague! tribunes for them!
The mouse ne'er shunned the cat as they did budge
From rascals worse than they.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: But how prevailed you?

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Will the time serve to tell? I do not think.
Where is the enemy? are you lords a' the field?
If not, why cease you till you are so?

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Marcius,
We have at disadvantage fought and did
Retire to win our purpose.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: How lies their battle? know you on which side
They have placed their men of trust?

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: As I guess, Marcius,
Their bands i' the vaward are the Antiates,
Of their best trust; o'er them Aufidius,
Their very heart of hope.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I do beseech you,
By all the battles wherein we have fought,
By the blood we have shed together, by the vows
We have made to endure friends, that you directly
Set me against Aufidius and his Antiates;
And that you not delay the present, but,
Filling the air with swords advanced and darts,
We prove this very hour.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Though I could wish
You were conducted to a gentle bath
And balms applied to you, yet dare I never
Deny your asking: take your choice of those
That best can aid your action.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Those are they
That most are willing: If any such be here
( As it were sin to doubt) that love this painting
Wherein you see me smeared; if any fear
Lesser his person than an ill report;
If any think brave death outweighs bad life
And that his country's dearer than himself;
Let him alone, or so many so minded,
Wave thus, to express his disposition,
And follow Marcius. They all shout and wave their swords, take him up in their arms, and cast up their caps.
O, me alone! make you a sword of me?
If these shows be not outward, which of you
But is four Volsces? none of you but is
Able to bear against the great Aufidius
A shield as hard as his. A certain number,
Though thanks to all, must I select from all: the rest
Shall bear the business in some other fight,
As cause will be obeyed. Please you to march;
And four shall quickly draw out my command,
Which men are best inclined.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: March on, my fellows:
Make good this ostentation, and you shall
Divide in all with us. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 7
div.stage: TITUS LARTIUS, having set a guard upon Corioles, going with drum and trumpet toward COMINIUS and CAIUS MARCIUS, enters with a Lieutenant, other Soldiers, and a Scout.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: So, let the ports be guarded: keep your duties,
As I have set them down. If I do send, dispatch
Those centuries to our aid; the rest will serve
For a short holding: if we lose the field,
We cannot keep the town.

sp.speaker: Lieutenant
sp.l: Fear not our care, sir.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Hence, and shut your gates upon's.
Our guider, come; to the Roman camp conduct us. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 8
div.stage: Alarum as in battle. Enter, from opposite sides, MARCIUS and AUFIDIUS.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I'll fight with none but thee; for I do hate thee
Worse than a promise-breaker.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: We hate alike:
Not Afric owns a serpent I abhor
More than thy fame and envy. Fix thy foot.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Let the first budger die the other's slave,
And the gods doom him after!

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: If I fly, Marcius,
Holloa me like a hare.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Within these three hours, Tullus,
Alone I fought in your Corioles walls,
And made what work I pleased: 'tis not my blood
Wherein thou seest me masked; for thy revenge
Wrench up thy power to the highest.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: Wert thou the Hector
That was the whip of your bragged progeny,
Thou shouldst not scape me here. They fight and certain Volsces come in the aid of Aufidius. Marcius fights till they be driven in breathless.
Officious, and not valiant, you have shamed me
In your condemned seconds. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 9
div.stage: Flourish. Alarum. A retreat is sounded. Flourish.
Enter, from one side, COMINIUS with the Romans; from the other side, MARCIUS, with his arm in a scarf.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: If I should tell thee o'er this thy day's work,
Thou't not believe thy deeds: but I'll report it
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles,
Where great patricians shall attend and shrug,
I' the end admire, where ladies shall be frighted,
And, gladly quaked, hear more; where the dull tribunes,
That, with the fusty plebeians, hate thine honours,
Shall say against their hearts âWe thank the gods
Our Rome hath such a soldier.â
Yet camest thou to a morsel of this feast,
Having fully dined before. Enter TITUS LARTIUS, with his power, from the pursuit.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: O general,
Here is the steed, we the caparison:
Hadst thou beheld

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: Pray now, no more: my mother,
Who has a charter to extol her blood,
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
As you have done; that's what I can; induced
As you have been; that's for my country:
He that has but effected his good will
Hath overta'en mine act.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: You shall not be
The grave of your deserving; Rome must know
The value of her own: 'twere a concealment
Worse than a theft, no less than a traducement,
To hide your doings; and to silence that,
Which, to the spire and top of praises vouched
Would seem but modest: therefore, I beseech you
In sign of what you are, not to reward
What you have done, before our army hear me.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I have some wounds upon me, and they smart
To hear themselves remembered.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Should they not,
Well might they fester 'gainst ingratitude,
And tent themselves with death. Of all the horses,
Whereof we have ta'en good and good store, of all
The treasure in this field achieved and city,
We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth,
Before the common distribution, at
Your only choice.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: I thank you, general;
But cannot make my heart consent to take
A bribe to pay my sword: I do refuse it;
And stand upon my common part with those
That have beheld the doing. A long flourish. They all cry âMarcius! Marcius!â cast up their caps and lances: Cominius and Lartius stand bare.

sp.speaker: Caius Marcius
sp.l: May these same instruments, which you profane,
Never sound more! when drums and trumpets shall
I' the field prove flatterers, let courts and cities be
Made all of false-faced soothing!
When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk,
Let him be made an overture for the wars!
No more, I say! For that I have not washed
My nose that bled, or foiled some debile wretch,
Which, without note, here's many else have done,
You shout me forth
In acclamations hyperbolical;
As if I loved my little should be dieted
In praises sauced with lies.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Too modest are you;
More cruel to your good report than grateful
To us that give you truly: by your patience,
If 'gainst yourself you be incensed, we'll put you,
Like one that means his proper harm, in manacles,
Then reason safely with you. Therefore, be it known,
As to us, to all the world, that Caius Marcius
Wears this war's garland: in token of the which,
My noble steed, known to the camp, I give him,
With all his trim belonging; and from this time,
For what he did before Corioles, call him,
With all th' applause and clamour of the host,
Marcius Caius Coriolanus! Bear
The addition nobly ever! Flourish. Trumpets sound, and drums.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Marcius Caius Coriolanus!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: I will go wash;
And when my face is fair, you shall perceive
Whether I blush or no: howbeit, I thank you.
I mean to stride your steed, and at all times
To undercrest your good addition
To the fairness of my power.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: So, to our tent;
Where, ere we do repose us, we will write
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
Must to Corioles back: send us to Rome
The best, with whom we may articulate,
For their own good and ours.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: I shall, my lord.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: The gods begin to mock me. I, that now
Refused most princely gifts, am bound to beg
Of my lord general.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Take't; 'tis yours. What is't?

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: I sometime lay here in Corioles
At a poor man's house; he used me kindly:
He cried to me; I saw him prisoner;
But then Aufidius was within my view,
And wrath o'erwhelmed my pity: I request you
To give my poor host freedom.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: O, well begged!
Were he the butcher of my son, he should
Be free as is the wind. Deliver him, Titus.

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: Marcius, his name?

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: By Jupiter! forgot.
I am weary; yea, my memory is tired.
Have we no wine here?

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Go we to our tent:
The blood upon your visage dries; 'tis time
It should be looked to: come. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 1, Scene 10
div.stage: A flourish. Cornets. Enter TULLUS AUFIDIUS, bloody, with two or three Soldiers.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: The town is ta'en!

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: 'Twill be delivered back on good condition.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: Condition!
I would I were a Roman; for I cannot,
Being a Volsce, be that I am. Condition!
What good condition can a treaty find
I' the part that is at mercy? Five times, Marcius,
I have fought with thee; so often hast thou beat me,
And wouldst do so, I think, should we encounter
As often as we eat. By the elements,
If e'er again I meet him beard to beard,
He's mine, or I am his: mine emulation
Hath not that honour in't it had; for where
I thought to crush him in an equal force,
True sword to sword, I'll potch at him some way
Or wrath or craft may get him.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: He's the devil.

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: Bolder, though not so subtle. My valour's poisoned
With only suffering stain by him; for him
Shall fly out of itself: nor sleep nor sanctuary,
Being naked, sick, nor fane nor Capitol,
The prayers of priests nor times of sacrifice,
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
Their rotten privilege and custom 'gainst
My hate to Marcius: where I find him, were it
At home, upon my brother's guard, even there,
Against the hospitable canon, would I
Wash my fierce hand in's heart. Go you to the city;
Learn how 'tis held; and what they are that must
Be hostages for Rome.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: Will not you go?

sp.speaker: Aufidius
sp.l: I am attended at the cypress grove: I pray you
'Tis south the city mills â bring me word thither
How the world goes, that to the pace of it
I may spur on my journey.

sp.speaker: First Soldier
sp.l: I shall, sir. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 1
div.stage: Enter MENENIUS with the two Tribunes of the people, SICINIUS and BRUTUS.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: The augurer tells me we shall have news to-night.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: Good or bad?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Not according to the prayer of the people, for they
love not Marcius.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.ab: Nature teaches beasts to know their friends.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Pray you, who does the wolf love?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.ab: The lamb.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Ay, to devour him; as the hungry plebeians would the
noble Marcius.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: He's a lamb indeed, that baes like a bear.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: He's a bear indeed, that lives like a lamb. You
two are old men: tell me one thing that I shall ask
you.

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.ab: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: In what enormity is Marcius poor in, that you two have
not in abundance?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: He's poor in no one fault, but stored with all

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.ab: Especially in pride.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: And topping all others in boasting.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: This is strange now: do you two know how you are
censured here in the city, I mean of us a' the
right-hand file? do you?

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.ab: Why, how are we censured?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Because you talk of pride now â will you not be angry?

sp.speaker: Both Tribunes
sp.ab: Well, well, sir, well.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Why, 'tis no great matter; for a very little
thief of occasion will rob you of a great deal
of patience: give your dispositions the reins,
and be angry at your pleasures; at the least, if
you take it as a pleasure to you in being so. You
blame Marcius for being proud?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: We do it not alone, sir.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: I know you can do very little alone; for your
helps are many, or else your actions would grow
wondrous single: your abilities are too infant-like
for doing much alone. You talk of pride: O that
you could turn your eyes toward the napes of your
necks, and make but an interior survey of your good
selves! O that you could!

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: What then, sir?

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Why, then you should discover a brace of unmeriting,
proud, violent, testy magistrates, alias fools, as any
in Rome.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.ab: Menenius, you are known well enough too.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: I am known to be a humorous patrician, and one
that loves a cup of hot wine with not a drop of
allaying Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect
in favouring the first complaint; hasty and
tinder-like upon too trivial motion; one that
converses more with the buttock of the night than
with the forehead of the morning: what I think
I utter, and spend my malice in my breath. Meeting
two such wealsmen as you are ( I cannot call you
Lycurguses) if the drink you give me touch my
palate adversely, I make a crooked face at it.
I cannot say your worships have delivered the
matter well, when I find the ass in compound with
the major part of your syllables: and though I
must be content to bear with those that say you
are reverend grave men, yet they lie deadly that
tell you have good faces. If you see this in the
map of my microcosm, follows it that I am known
well enough too? what harm can your bisson
conspectuities glean out of this character, if I be
known well enough too?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: Come, sir, come, we know you well enough.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: You know neither me, yourselves, nor any thing.
You are ambitious for poor knaves' caps and legs:
you wear out a good wholesome forenoon in hearing
a cause between an orange-wife and a fosset-seller;
and then rejourn the controversy of threepence
to a second day of audience. When you are hearing
a matter between party and party, if you chance
to be pinched with the colic, you make faces like
mummers; set up the bloody flag against all
patience; and, in roaring for a chamber-pot,
dismiss the controversy bleeding, the more
entangled by your hearing: all the peace you make
in their cause is, calling both the parties knaves.
You are a pair of strange ones.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.ab: Come, come, you are well understood to be a
perfecter giber for the table than a necessary bencher
in the Capitol.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Our very priests must become mockers, if they
shall encounter such ridiculous subjects as you
are. When you speak best unto the purpose, it is
not worth the wagging of your beards; and your
beards deserve not so honourable a grave as to
stuff a botcher's cushion, or to be entombed in
an ass's pack-saddle. Yet you must be saying,
Marcius is proud; who, in a cheap estimation, is
worth all your predecessors since Deucalion,
though peradventure some of the best of 'em were
hereditary hangmen. God-den to your worships:
more of your conversation would infect my brain,
being the herdsmen of the beastly plebeians: I will be
bold to take my leave of you.
How now, my as fair as noble ladies, and the
moon, were she earthly, no nobler, whither do you
follow your eyes so fast?

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Honourable Menenius, my boy Marcius approaches; for
the love of Juno, let's go.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Ha! Marcius coming home!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Ay, worthy Menenius; and with most prosperous
approbation.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Take my cap, Jupiter, and I thank thee. Hoo! Marcius
coming home!

sp.speaker: Volumnia and Virgilia
sp.ab: Nay, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Look, here's a letter from him: the state hath
another, his wife another; and, I think, there's one
at home for you.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: I will make my very house reel to-night: a letter for
me!

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: Yes, certain, there's a letter for you; I saw't.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: A letter for me! it gives me an estate of seven
years' health; in which time I will make a lip
at the physician: the most sovereign prescription
in Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this
preservative, of no better report than a
horse-drench. Is he not wounded? he was wont to come
home wounded.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: O, no, no, no.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: O, he is wounded; I thank the gods for't.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: So do I too, if it be not too much: brings 'a victory
in his pocket? the wounds become him.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: On's brows: Menenius, he comes the third time home
with the oaken garland.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Has he disciplined Aufidius soundly?

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but
Aufidius got off.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: And 'twas time for him too, I'll warrant him
that: and he had stayed by him, I would not have
been so fidiused for all the chests in Corioles,
and the gold that's in them. Is the senate possessed
of this?

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: Good ladies, let's go. Yes, yes, yes; the senate
has letters from the general, wherein he gives
my son the whole name of the war: he hath in this
action outdone his former deeds doubly.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.ab: In troth, there's wondrous things spoke of him.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Wondrous! ay, I warrant you, and not without his true
purchasing.

sp.speaker: Virgilia
sp.ab: The gods grant them true!

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: True! pow waw.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: True! I'll be sworn they are true. Where is he
wounded?
God save your good worships! Marcius is coming
home: he has more cause to be proud. Where is he
wounded?

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: I' the shoulder and i' the left arm: there will
be large cicatrices to show the people, when he
shall stand for his place. He received in the repulse
of Tarquin seven hurts i' the body.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: One i' the neck, and two i' the thigh there's nine
that I know.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: He had, before this last expedition, twenty-five
wounds upon him.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.ab: Now it's twenty-seven: every gash was an enemy's
grave.
Hark! the trumpets.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.ab: These are the ushers of Marcius: before him he carries
noise, and behind him he leaves tears:
sp.l: Death, that dark spirit, in's nervy arm doth lie:

Which, being advanced, declines, and then men die. A sennet. Trumpets sound. Enter COMINIUS the general, and TITUS LARTIUS; between them, CORIOLANUS, crowned with an oaken garland; with Captains and Soldiers, and a Herald.

sp.speaker: Roman Herald
sp.l: Know, Rome, that all alone Marcius did fight
Within Corioles gates: where he hath won,
With fame, a name to Marcius Caius; these
In honour follows Coriolanus.
Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus! Flourish.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Welcome to Rome, renowned Coriolanus!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: No more of this; it does offend my heart:
Pray now, no more.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Look, sir, your mother!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: O,
You have, I know, petitioned all the gods
For my prosperity! Kneels.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.l: Nay, my good soldier, up;
My gentle Marcius, worthy Caius, and
By deed-achieving honour newly named,
What is it? Coriolanus must I call thee?
But, O, thy wife!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: My gracious silence, hail!
Wouldst thou have laughed had I come coffined home,
That weep'st to see me triumph? Ah, my dear,
Such eyes the widows in Corioles wear,
And mothers that lack sons.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Now, the gods crown thee!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: And live you yet? To Valeria
O my sweet lady, pardon.

sp.speaker: Valeria
sp.l: I know not where to turn: O, welcome home:
And welcome, general, and y' are welcome all.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: A hundred thousand welcomes. I could weep
And I could laugh, I am light and heavy.
Welcome.
A curse begin at very root on's heart,
That is not glad to see thee! You are three
That Rome should dote on: yet, by the faith of men,
We have some old crab-trees here at home that will not
Be grafted to your relish. Yet welcome, warriors:
We call a nettle but a nettle and
The faults of fools but folly.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Ever right.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Menenius ever, ever.

sp.speaker: Roman Herald
sp.l: Give way there, and go on!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Your hand, and yours:
Ere in our own house I do shade my head,
The good patricians must be visited;
From whom I have received not only greetings,
But with them change of honours.

sp.speaker: Volumnia
sp.l: I have lived
To see inherited my very wishes
And the buildings of my fancy: only
There's one thing wanting, which I doubt not but
Our Rome will cast upon thee.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Know, good mother,
I had rather be their servant in my way
Than sway with them in theirs.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: On, to the Capitol! Flourish. Cornets. Exeunt in state, as before. Brutus and Sicinius come forward.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: All tongues speak of him, and the bleared sights
Are spectacled to see him: your prattling nurse
Into a rapture lets her baby cry
While she chats him: the kitchen malkin pins
Her richest lockram 'bout her reechy neck,
Clambering the walls to eye him: stalls, bulks, windows,
Are smothered up, leads filled, and ridges horsed
With variable complexions, all agreeing
In earnestness to see him: seld-shown flamens
Do press among the popular throngs and puff
To win a vulgar station: our veiled dames
Commit the war of white and damask in
Their nicely gawded cheeks to the wanton spoil
Of Phoebus' burning kisses: such a pother
As if that whatsoever god who leads him
Were slily crept into his human powers
And gave him graceful posture.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: On the sudden,
I warrant him consul.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Then our office may,
During his power, go sleep.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: He cannot temperately transport his honours
From where he should begin and end, but will
Lose those he hath won.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: In that there's comfort.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Doubt not
The commoners, for whom we stand, but they
Upon their ancient malice will forget
With the least cause these his new honours, which
That he will give them make I as little question
As he is proud to do't.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: I heard him swear,
Were he to stand for consul, never would he
Appear i' the marketplace nor on him put
The napless vesture of humility;
Nor, showing, as the manner is, his wounds
To the people, beg their stinking breaths.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: 'Tis right.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: It was his word: O, he would miss it rather
Than carry it but by the suit of the gentry to him
And the desire of the nobles.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: I wish no better
Than have him hold that purpose and to put it
In execution.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: 'Tis most like he will.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: It shall be to him then as our good wills,
A sure destruction.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: So it must fall out
To him or our authorities. For an end,
We must suggest the people in what hatred
He still hath held them; that to's power he would
Have made them mules, silenced their pleaders and
Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them,
In human action and capacity,
Of no more soul nor fitness for the world
Than camels in their war, who have their provand
Only for bearing burdens, and sore blows
For sinking under them.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: This, as you say, suggested
At some time when his soaring insolence
Shall teach the people which time shall not want,
If he be put upon't; and that's as easy
As to set dogs on sheep â will be his fire
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
Shall darken him for ever. Enter a Messenger.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: You are sent for to the Capitol. 'Tis thought
That Marcius shall be consul:
I have seen the dumb men throng to see him and
The blind to hear him speak: matrons flung gloves,
Ladies and maids their scarfs and handkerchers,
Upon him as he passed: the nobles bended,
As to Jove's statue, and the commons made
A shower and thunder with their caps and shouts:
I never saw the like.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Let's to the Capitol;
And carry with us ears and eyes for the time,
But hearts for the event.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Have with you. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 2, Scene 2
div.stage: Enter two Officers, to lay cushions.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.ab: Come, come, they are almost here. How many stand for
consulships?

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.ab: Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one
Coriolanus will carry it.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.ab: That's a brave fellow; but he's vengeance proud, and
loves not the common people.

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.ab: Faith, there hath been many great men that have
flattered the people, who ne'er loved them; and
there be many that they have loved, they know
not wherefore; so that, if they love they know
not why, they hate upon no better a ground:
therefore, for Coriolanus neither to care whether
they love or hate him manifests the true knowledge
he has in their disposition; and out of his noble
carelessness lets them plainly see't.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.ab: If he did not care whether he had their love or
no, he waved indifferently 'twixt doing them
neither good nor harm: but he seeks their hate
with greater devotion than they can render it
him; and leaves nothing undone that may fully
discover him their opposite. Now, to seem to
affect the malice and displeasure of the people
is as bad as that which he dislikes, to flatter them
for their love.

sp.speaker: Second Officer
sp.ab: He hath deserved worthily of his country: and
his ascent is not by such easy degrees as those
who, having been supple and courteous to the
people, bonneted, without any further deed to
have them at all into their estimation and report:
but he hath so planted his honours in their eyes,
and his actions in their hearts, that for their
tongues to be silent, and not confess so much,
were a kind of ingrateful injury; to report
otherwise, were a malice, that, giving itself
the lie, would pluck reproof and rebuke from every ear
that heard it.

sp.speaker: First Officer
sp.ab: No more of him; he's a worthy man: make way, they are
coming.
sp.stage: A sennet. Enter, with Lictors before them, COMINIUS the consul, MENENIUS, CORIOLANUS, Senators, SICINIUS and BRUTUS. The Senators take their places; the Tribunes take their places by themselves. CORIOLANUS stands.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Having determined of the Volsces and
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
As the main point of this our after-meeting,
To gratify his noble service that
Hath thus stood for his country: therefore, please you
Most reverend and grave elders, to desire
The present consul, and last general
In our well-found successes, to report
A little of that worthy work performed
By Marcius Caius Coriolanus, whom
We met here both to thank and to remember
With honours like himself.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Speak, good Cominius:
Leave nothing out for length, and make us think
Rather our state's defective for requital
Than we to stretch it out. To the Tribunes
Masters a' the people,
We do request your kindest ears, and after,
Your loving motion toward the common body,
To yield what passes here.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: We are convented
Upon a pleasing treaty, and have hearts
Inclinable to honour and advance
The theme of our assembly.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Which the rather
We shall be blest to do, if he remember
A kinder value of the people than
He hath hereto prized them at.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: That's off, that's off;
I would you rather had been silent. Please you
To hear Cominius speak?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Most willingly;
But yet my caution was more pertinent
Than the rebuke you give it.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: He loves your people;
But tie him not to be their bedfellow.
Worthy Cominius, speak. Coriolanus offers to go away.
Nay, keep your place.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Sit, Coriolanus; never shame to hear
What you have nobly done.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Your honours' pardon:
I had rather have my wounds to heal again
Than hear say how I got them.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Sir, I hope
My words disbenched you not.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: No, sir: yet oft,
When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.
You soothed not, therefore hurt not: but your people,
I love them as they weigh.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Pray now, sit down.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: I had rather have one scratch my head i' the sun
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
To hear my nothings monstered. Exit.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Masters of the people,
Your multiplying spawn how can he flatter
That's thousand to one good one â when you now see
He had rather venture all his limbs for honour
Than one on's ears to hear it? Proceed, Cominius.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: I shall lack voice: the deeds of Coriolanus
Should not be uttered feebly. It is held
That valour is the chiefest virtue, and
Most dignifies the haver: if it be,
The man I speak of cannot in the world
Be singly counterpoised. At sixteen years,
When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
Beyond the mark of others: our then dictator,
Whom with all praise I point at, saw him fight,
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
The bristled lips before him: he bestrid
An o'erpressed Roman and i' the consul's view
Slew three opposers: Tarquin's self he met,
And struck him on his knee: in that day's feats,
When he might act the woman in the scene,
He proved best man i' the field, and for his meed
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Man-entered thus, he waxed like a sea,
And in the brunt of seventeen battles since
He lurched all swords of the garland. For this last,
Before and in Corioles, let me say,
I cannot speak him home: he stopped the fliers;
And by his rare example made the coward
Turn terror into sport: as weeds before
A vessel under sail, so men obeyed
And fell below his stem: his sword, death's stamp,
Where it did mark, it took; from face to foot
He was a thing of blood, whose every motion
Was timed with dying cries: alone he entered
The mortal gate of the city, which he painted
With shunless destiny; aidless came off,
And with a sudden reinforcement struck
Corioles like a planet: now all's his:
When, by and by, the din of war 'gan pierce
His ready sense; then straight his doubled spirit
Requickened what in flesh was fatigate,
And to the battle came he; where he did
Run reeking o'er the lives of men, as if
'Twere a perpetual spoil: and till we called
Both field and city ours, he never stood
To ease his breast with panting.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Worthy man!

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: He cannot but with measure fit the honours
Which we devise him.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: Our spoils he kicked at,
And looked upon things precious as they were
The common muck of the world: he covets less
Than misery itself would give; rewards
His deeds with doing them, and is content
To spend the time to end it.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: He's right noble:
Let him be called for.

sp.speaker: First Senator
sp.l: Call Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.l: He doth appear. Re-enter CORIOLANUS.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: The senate, Coriolanus, are well pleased
To make thee consul.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: I do owe them still
My life and services.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: It then remains
That you do speak to the people.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: I do beseech you,
Let me o'erleap that custom, for I cannot
Put on the gown, stand naked and entreat them,
For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you
That I may pass this doing.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Sir, the people
Must have their voices; neither will they bate
One jot of ceremony.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Put them not to't:
Pray you, go fit you to the custom and
Take to you, as your predecessors have,
Your honour with your form.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: It is a part
That I shall blush in acting, and might well
Be taken from the people.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Mark you that?

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;
Show them the unaching scars which I should hide,
As if I had received them for the hire
Of their breath only!

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: Do not stand upon't.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
Our purpose to them: and to our noble consul
Wish we all joy and honour.

sp.speaker: Senators
sp.l: To Coriolanus come all joy and honour! Flourish of cornets. Exeunt all but Sicinius and Brutus.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: You see how he intends to use the people.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: May they perceive's intent! He will require them,
As if he did contemn what he requested
Should be in them to give.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Come, we'll inform them
Of our proceedings here: on the marketplace,
I know, they do attend us. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to
deny him.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We may, sir, if we will.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is
a power that we have no power to do; for if he
show us his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are
to put our tongues into those wounds and speak
for them; so, if he tell us his noble deeds, we
must also tell him our noble acceptance of them.
Ingratitude is monstrous, and for the multitude
to be ingrateful, were to make a monster of the
multitude; of the which we being members, should bring
ourselves to be monstrous members.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: And to make us no better thought of, a little
help will serve; for once we stood up about the
corn, he himself stuck not to call us the many-headed
multitude.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We have been called so of many; not that our
heads are some brown, some black, some Abram,
some bald, but that our wits are so diversely
coloured: and truly I think if all our wits were
to issue out of one skull, they would fly east,
west, north, south, and their consent of one
direct way should be at once to all the points a' the
compass.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would fly?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another
man's will; 'tis strongly wedged up in a blockhead,
but if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Why that way?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts
melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would
return for conscience' sake, to help to get thee a
wife.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But
that's no matter, the greater part carries it.
I say, if he would incline to the people, there was
never a worthier man.
sp.stage: Enter CORIOLANUS in a gown of humility, with MENENIUS.
sp.ab: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark
his behaviour. We are not to stay all together,
but to come by him where he stands, by ones, by
twos, and by threes. He's to make his requests
by particulars; wherein every one of us has a
single honour, in giving him our own voices with
our own tongues: therefore follow me, and I'll direct
you how you shall go by him.

sp.speaker: All
sp.ab: Content, content.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: O sir, you are not right: have you not known
The worthiest men have done't?

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: What must I say?
âI pray, sir,â â Plague upon't! I cannot bring
My tongue to such a pace: âLook, sir, my wounds!
I got them in my country's service, when
Some certain of your brethren roared and ran
From the noise of our own drums.â

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: O me, the gods!
You must not speak of that: you must desire them
To think upon you.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Think upon me! hang'em!
I would they would forget me, like the virtues
Which our divines lose by 'em.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: You'll mar all:
I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you,
In wholesome manner. Exit.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Bid them wash their faces
And keep their teeth clean. Re-enter two of the Citizens. So, here comes a brace. Re-enter a third Citizen.
You know the cause, sir, of my standing here.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Mine own desert.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Your own desert!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Ay, not mine own desire.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: How not your own desire?

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: No, sir, 'twas never my desire yet to trouble the poor
with begging.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to
gain by you.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Well then, I pray, your price a' the consulship?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: The price is to ask it kindly.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds
to show you, which shall be yours in private. Your
good voice, sir; what say you?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You shall ha't, worthy sir.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices begged.
I have your alms: adieu.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: But this is something odd.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: And 'twere to give again, but 'tis no matter.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of
your voices that I may be consul, I have here the
customary gown.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you have
not deserved nobly.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Your enigma?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have
been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved
the common people.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: You should account me the more virtuous that I
have not been common in my love. I will, sir,
flatter my sworn brother, the people, to earn a
dearer estimation of them; 'tis a condition they
account gentle: and since the wisdom of their
choice is rather to have my hat than my heart,
I will practise the insinuating nod and be off
to them most counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will
counterfeit the bewitchment of some popular man
and give it bountiful to the desirers. Therefore,
beseech you, I may be consul.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give you
our voices heartily.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: You have received many wounds for your country.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them.
I will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no
further.

sp.speaker: Both Citizens
sp.ab: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Most sweet voices!
Better it is to die, better to starve,
Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.
Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here,
To beg of Hob and Dick, that does appear,
Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:
What custom wills, in all things should we do't,
The dust on antique time would lie unswept,
And mountainous error be too highly heaped
For truth to o'erpeer. Rather than fool it so,
Let the high office and the honour go
To one that would do thus. I am half through;
The one part suffered, the other will I do. Re-enter three Citizens more.
Here come more voices.
Your voices: for your voices I have fought;
Watched for your voices; for your voices bear
Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six
I have seen and heard of; for your voices have
Done many things, some less, some more: your voices:
Indeed, I would be consul.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest
man's voice.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.ab: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy,
and make him good friend to the people!

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.ab: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.ab: Worthy voices!
sp.stage: Re-enter MENENIUS, with BRUTUS and SICINIUS.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes
Endue you with the people's voice: remains
That, in the official marks invested, you
Anon do meet the senate.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Is this done?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: The custom of request you have discharged:
The people do admit you, and are summoned
To meet anon, upon your approbation.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Where? at the senatehouse?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: There, Coriolanus.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: May I change these garments?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: You may, sir.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again,
Repair to the senatehouse.

sp.speaker: Menenius
sp.l: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: We stay here for the people.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Fare you well. Exeunt Coriolanus and Menenius.
He has it now, and by his looks methinks
'Tis warm at's heart.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.
Will you dismiss the people? Re-enter Citizens.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: He has our voices, sir.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice,
He mocked us when he begged our voices.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Certainly
He flouted us downright.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: No, 'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says
He used us scornfully: he should have showed us
His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Why, so he did, I am sure.

sp.speaker: Citizens
sp.l: No, no; no man saw 'em.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: He said he had wounds, which he could show in private;
And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,
âI would be consul,â says he: âaged custom,
But by your voices, will not so permit me;
Your voices therefore.â When we granted that,
Here was âI thank you for your voices: thank you:
Your most sweet voices: now you have left your voices,
I have no further with you.â Was not this mockery?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Why either were you ignorant to see't,
Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness
To yield your voices?

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Could you not have told him
As you were lessoned, when he had no power,
But was a petty servant to the state,
He was your enemy, ever spake against
Your liberties and the charters that you bear
I' the body of the weal; and now, arriving
A place of potency and sway o' the state,
If he should still malignantly remain
Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might
Be curses, to yourselves? You should have said
That as his worthy deeds did claim no less
Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature
Would think upon you for your voices and
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Standing your friendly lord.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Thus to have said,
As you were fore-advised, had touched his spirit
And tried his inclination; from him plucked
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
As cause had called you up, have held him to;
Or else it would have galled his surly nature,
Which easily endures not article
Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage,
You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler
And passed him unelected.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Did you perceive
He did solicit you in free contempt
When he did need your loves, and do you think
That his contempt shall not be bruising to you,
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry
Against the rectorship of judgement?

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Have you
Ere now denied the asker? and now again
Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow
Your sued-for tongues?

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: He's not confirmed; we may deny him yet.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: And will deny him:
I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.

sp.speaker: Citizen
sp.l: I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,
They have chose a consul that will from them take
Their liberties: make them of no more voice
Than dogs that are as often beat for barking
As therefore kept to do so.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Let them assemble,
And on a safer judgement all revoke
Your ignorant election; enforce his pride,
And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not
With what contempt he wore the humble weed,
How in his suit he scorned you; but your loves,
Thinking upon his services, took from you
The apprehension of his present portance,
Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion
After the inveterate hate he bears you.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Lay
A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured,
No impediment between, but that you must
Cast your election on him.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: Say, you chose him
More after our commandment than as guided
By your own true affections, and that your minds,
Preoccupied with what you rather must do
Than what you should, made you against the grain
To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you,
How youngly he began to serve his country,
How long continued, and what stock he springs of,
The noble house o' the Marcians, from whence came
That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,
Who, after great Hostilius, here was king;
Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,
That our best water brought by conduits hither;
And Censorinus that was so surnamed,
And nobly named so, twice being censor,
Was his great ancestor.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: One thus descended,
That hath beside well in his person wrought
To be set high in place, we did commend
To your remembrances: but you have found,
Scaling his present bearing with his past,
That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke
Your sudden approbation.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Say, you ne'er had done't
Harp on that still â but by our putting on:
And presently, when you have drawn your number,
Repair to the Capitol.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: We will so: almost all
Repent in their election. Exeunt Citizens.

sp.speaker: Brutus
sp.l: Let them go on;
This mutiny were better put in hazard,
Than stay, past doubt, for greater:
If, as his nature is, he fall in rage
With their refusal, both observe and answer
The vantage of his anger.

sp.speaker: Sicinius
sp.l: To the Capitol, come:
We will be there before the stream o' the people;
And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own,
Which we have goaded onward. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 3, Scene 1
div.stage: Cornets. Enter CORIOLANUS, MENENIUS, all the Gentry, COMINIUS, TITUS LARTIUS, and other Senators.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Tullus Aufidius then had made new head?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: He had, my lord; and that it was which caused
Our swifter composition.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: So then the Volsces stand but as at first,
Ready, when time shall prompt them, to make road
Upon's again.

sp.speaker: Cominius
sp.l: They are worn, lord consul, so,
That we shall hardly in our ages see
Their banners wave again.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Saw you Aufidius?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: On safeguard he came to me; and did curse
Against the Volsces, for they had so vilely
Yielded the town: he is retired to Antium.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: Spoke he of me?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: He did, my lord.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: How? what?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: How often he had met you, sword to sword;
That of all things upon the earth he hated
Your person most, that he would pawn his fortunes
To hopeless restitution, so he might
Be called your vanquisher.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
sp.l: At Antium lives he?

sp.speaker: Lartius
sp.l: At Antium.

sp.speaker: Coriolanus
